title: 111_hr5458
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The "Christopher Bryski Student Loan Protection Act" and "Christopher's Law" address the lack of requirements for educational lenders to provide information on durable power of attorney and responsibilities in case of borrower or cosigner incapacitation or death. Additionally, statistics on traumatic brain and spinal cord injuries are highlighted. In the United States, the annual incidence of spinal cord injury is estimated to be around 40 cases per 1,000,000 people, resulting in approximately 12,000 new cases each year. In 2007-2008, 13% of students at public schools and 26.2% at private schools borrowed money from private lenders, with a significant increase in cosigned private education loans in 2009. SEC. 2. ADDITIONAL STUDENT LOAN PROTECTIONS. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include additional protections for borrowers and cosigners of private education loans related to death or disability. Covered educational institutions must provide information on creating a durable power of attorney for financial decision-making, and private educational lenders must also provide this information to borrowers and cosigners. The private educational lender must provide clear information to the borrower and cosigner about creating a durable power of attorney for financial decision-making. Additionally, the lender must describe the cosigner's obligations in writing, including the impact of death, disability, or inability to work on the loan obligation. The Board will publish model forms for the required information. The Board will publish model forms for the required information on durable power of attorney for financial decision-making and cosigner obligations in case of death, disability, or inability to work. The definition of these conditions will align with regulations prescribed by the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Board will publish model forms for durable power of attorney, aligning with regulations from the Higher Education Act of 1965. The definition includes written instructions for financial decision-making when an individual lacks capacity. The Uniform Durable Power of Attorney Act of 2006 and sections 5-501 through 5-505 of the Uniform Probate Code define a cosigner as an individual liable for another's obligation without compensation, including those whose signature is required for credit or collection purposes, but excluding a spouse needed to perfect a security interest in a loan. SEC. 3. FEDERAL STUDENT LOANS. Section 485(l)(2) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include information on loan discharge due to death, disability, or inability to work, as well as details on repayment obligations for private education loans. Additionally, it includes a requirement for institutions to provide a model form for durable power of attorneys as published by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Federal Reserve System requires institutions to provide a model form for durable power of attorneys as published by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The House of Representatives passed the document on September 28, 2010, with LORRAINE C. MILLER as the Clerk.
